Description: Ovoid marl pottery vase with two pierced cylindrical handles on the shoulder and a flat ledge rim; decorated in dark red paint on each side with representations of a many oared boat and an animal skin on pole motif flanked by two cabins below. Horizontal lines appear above and over the handles; below the handles on each is a so-called Naqada plant. The rim is painted with cross-hatched lines, the base has a spiral.
Curator's comments: Like Decorated ware D41N in Petrie’s Corpus of Prehistoric Pottery (1921). One boat a three-triangle standard, the other has a Z-motif standard. Both are appended to the left cabin. Published:J.H. Taylor & D. Antoine, Ancient lives, new discoveries, London 2014, p. 36. G. Graff, Les peintures sur vases de Naqada I–Naqada II: Nouvelle approche sémiologique de l’iconographie prédynastique, Leuven (2009), cat. no. 412.
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 1986 Jun-Oct, Carmarthen Museum, A son of Luxor's Sands
